column4: I'm still having trouble figuring out how to mount a drive i have =\
what kind of drive, file system, etc?
regular ol' IDE HD, ntfs but I only need it for reading files anyway
that has nothing to do with the permissions of the mount point
you need the options uid= and gid= on the mount command.
hmm, what do i have to do to repair this?
it's a kludge for handling file systems that don't implement permissions
umount it, and mount it again with the options.
if it's ntfs, qman has a good point
there is ntfs write support that is supposedly safe, but it is much too new to rely on IMO
I don't need the write support at the moment so read only is fine
hmm, then I must have misunderstood your question.
anyway, what I was talking about applies to which user can access the files.  even on a read only mount, you may need uid=/gid= to allow the desired user to read the files.
you don't need write support to read.  :)
so what would the command be? what do i put for uid and gid?
at the command prompt, do the "id" command.  it will tell you the user and group IDs
will doing this add that awesome hard drive icon onto my desktop too? ;D
I don't think so, no.  I don't bother with icons.
could you run that mount command by me one more time? with the uid and gid?
if you are doing, say:   mount -t ntfs /dev/hda1 /mnt/something, you would do:  mount -t ntfs -o 'uid=500,gid=500' /dev/hda1 /mnt/something
of course 500 is an example, you have to use the correct numbers.  :)
excellent.
it's under $HOME/.mozilla
